ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION

SINGAPORE AIRLINES
(National Licensed Aircraft Engineers)


    1. Mr Phey Yew Kok asked the Minister for Finance if he will ascertain from the Singapore Airlines and inform the House (i) the present number of National Licensed Aircraft Engineers employed by the Airlines; (ii) the facilities that exist for training them; (iii) the number of such engineers who have resigned since the Airlines was formed; and (iv) the number of existing vacancies and the steps being taken to fill them with National Licensed Aircraft Engineers.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, I understand from Singapore Airlines that there are

Column: 968



166    Licensed Aircraft Engineers employed on national terms on 18th March, 1975.

    As for the facilities that exist for training them, apprentice engineers serve a five-year period of education and training at the Polytechnic, the SIA Engineering Training School and on the shop floor gaining practical experience. They spend the first year full-time at the Singapore Polytechnic; from the second to the fifth year they spend one day and two evenings a week at the Polytechnic. Their theoretical education is supplemented by instruction at the SIA Engineering Training School. The training is rounded off by on-the-job shop floor experience, chiefly in the last two years of apprenticeship. By the end of the fifth year they should be in possession not only of a Singapore Polytechnic

Column: 969

Diploma but also of two professional licences issued by the Singapore Director of Civil Aviation.

    Thirteen Licensed Aircraft Engineers on national terms have resigned since SIA was formed on 1st October, 1972.

    There are now 38 vacancies for staff at all levels required to hold aircraft engineer licences.

    The number of apprentice engineers is 257, of whom 12 will be completing their training in July of this year, 27 in August of next year, 37 in 1977, 113 in 1978 and the remaining 68 in 1979. S1A's manpower development plan provides for the recruitment of 85 apprentice engineers this year and thereafter 50 a year.

    Head W -

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head W be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1004*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs Tay Boon Too, Ang Nam Piau, L. P. Rodrigo, P. Govindaswamy, Sia Khoon Seong, N. Govindasamy and Ho Kah Leong.)

    Sir, I would like to make some comments on the restructure of the education system, to which a remarkable amount of publicity has been given during this Budget season - but outside the House. In the debate on the Minister of Finance's Budget statement, I did remark adversely on certain statements about restructure, but these statements were really marginal to the statement of basic principle. For example, I disagreed that the changes in the past 15 years had been minor and I also felt that there could have been more consultation with teachers and teachers' bodies over the definition of policy.

    But having said this, where the basic principles germane to restructure are concerned, such principles have been stated in a manner that makes the restructure look like the answer to every teacher's prayer. Behold, Mr Speaker, Sir, schooling should be made a more meaningful and enjoyable experience; continual assessment of academic performance shall ensure that children are brought through their schooling with full appreciation of their abilities or their limitations. By implication the very intelligent would not find schooling a boring experience, and slow developers would receive due consideration. The promise is made that every student who has completed primary education will be channelled into some form of post-primary education or training. Thus by providing alternative avenues for different aptitudes, our resources will be optimally utilised.

Column: 971



    In a recent seminar on the restructure of the education system, suggestions were sought from participants who were principals from all over Singapore regarding how to achieve certain outcomes that were envisaged as following upon the aim to make schooling more meaningful and enjoyable and the aim to ensure continual assessment of academic performance. Now this is the real nub of the restructure intention: the determination to achieve this intention and to implement vigorously and steadily what has been conceived of as a good plan. Views have been sought over aspects of implementation. Now these views have been forthcoming, and in terms of stress on certain lines of action, some recommendations standing out quite clearly. For example, children should have pre-school experience through kindergarten; learning should be through activities and experience that appeal to the children's interest and imagination, as for instance, excursions, projects, effective use of apparatus and aids, the application of a variety of methods and techniques; resort to educational hardware, necessitating of course the production of corresponding soft ware, group teaching, multi-level teaching and close monitoring of progress through personal observation, informal questioning, written assignments, stage by stage, unit by unit. Above all, classroom size should be reduced.

    The Ministry of Education has come out with a classic education proposal. In soliciting views over implementation they have received classic educational answers. Teachers are looking forward to participating in this thrilling development. My observation has been that most teachers have stretched themselves to the limit in their work in schools. I am speaking here particularly of the primary schools where the new policy will be initiated. Without the organisation of manpower and resources to help the teachers, this proposal that has been presented with such a bang will end in a whimper. More manpower is required,

Column: 972

more training facilities and retraining facilities. And certainly the production of first class supervisors in the shape of capable education development officers who will really advise on development and not perpetuate the old inspectors role. All these are needed. In the conclusion to the official November statement on the restructure there was recognition of all these needs. If the Ministry makes its own response in a rational, positive, understanding manner, we need have no fear about how the teachers themselves will respond to the challenge.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in recent years the Ministry of Education has wielded the big axe in implementing the restructuring of our education system and introduction of new teaching methods. Such measures are not only necessary but also welcome. This is because, unlike other fields, education cannot remain as it has always been. We cannot teach new ideas with old methods. Teaching methods must be formulated to suit the needs of the country and changing circumstances. Only in this way can we bring forth a generation to meet the needs of the changing times in our country. But the new education system now being vigorously implemented should also cater for the objective need for adequate school buildings and other facilities, in addition to good quality teachers. Only in this way can we achieve maximum results.

    Sir, small schools in the rural areas have very little space. Their simple buildings are very old and dilapidated, and there is a total lack of facilities. In such circumstances, we can apply the saying which goes, "You may have the best cook, but he cannot cook without adequate ingredients." I, therefore, suggest that small schools in the rural areas should be amalgamated into larger schools.

2.45 p.m.

    The Ministry of Education should treat all schools alike and give the best possible financial aid to all the amalga

Column: 973

mated schools. It is only through an amalgamation of the small schools that we can ensure a certain standard of facilities and school buildings for the rural areas. It will then be in keeping with the implementation of the new education system. In this way, every child in Singapore will be able to enjoy the opportunity of a good education in better equipped surroundings and school buildings

    Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to bring up another matter, and that is in relation to the announcement of results of secondary and higher secondary school examinations in the newspapers. The results of the Primary School Leaving Examination are not normally published in the newspapers. Notwithstanding this, cases have been known where unsuccessful PSLE students have left their homes or their families. The results of Secondary IV and Pre-U or HSC examinations, however, are announced in the newspapers. As a result of such public announcement, some unsuccessful candidates would develop an inferiority complex by not seeing their names together with their classmates' in the newspapers. They feel that they are put in a very poor light, and are more or less put to public shame, so to speak. In such circumstances, those unsuccessful candidates who do not have a strong sense of morale would simply lose face and would even do very foolish things, unpleasant or even unfortunate. This is regrettable.

    I would therefore suggest that we cease the publication of examination results. The results can only be made known to all the candidates, including those from the Adult Education Board, by the school authorities or the AEB. Private candidates can be directly notified of their results through the post by the Ministry of Education. There is, therefore, no apparent need for the results of these examinations to be published in the newspapers, because such announcement may cause an unnecessary blow to unsuccessful candidates,

Column: 974

at least psychologically. I would therefore suggest to the Ministry of Education that henceforth results of the secondary school examinations should not be published in the newspapers. This practice should be abolished. I would, however, concede that the publication of the results of very outstanding students may continue, because it will then give encouragement to our students.

    Finally, Sir, I would like to touch on the question of Chinese stream Secondary IV students entering pre-U classes. In the case of the Chinese schools, those who desire to continue their studies in the upper secondary classes will only be allowed to join the classes after their results are known, so as to assess whether they possess the minimum standard of qualification specified by the Ministry of Education. So students wishing to join upper secondary classes have to wait for two to three months. And this year because the Secondary IV results were announced only in March, our poor students had to wait for nearly four months before they can enter the upper secondary classes to further their studies. We concede that it takes considerable time to mark the examination papers. But we must not forget that at the same time Secondary IV students in the English stream are allowed to join the upper secondary classes on the strength of the results of the preliminary examinations conducted by the schools. And after the official announcement of their results, they may either continue if their results meet the entry requirements specified by the Ministry of Education or drop out if they do not meet such requirements. Since this is allowed in the English stream, I wonder why it cannot be allowed in the Chinese stream.

    Sir, the Government has always been saying that all the four streams of education are treated equally. So how does one explain this discrepancy?

    Sir, I support the amendment moved by the Member for Katong.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson)(In Mandarin): Sir, education is the foundation for nation building. In recent years,

Column: 975

our education policy has laid stress on the importance of mathematics, science and technology and bi-lingualism in order to help in the promotion of nation building. But in doing so, the inculcation of character building, moral and ethical concepts in the students has been neglected by the Ministry of Education. We all know that there is the subject called "Ethics" or "Civics" taught in many schools but it is not considered as a subject for examination. Therefore, the students do not pay much attention to this subject and the teachers themselves lack interest in teaching it. In fact, some of them even use the Ethics period to teach other subjects. As a result, the inculcation of the concept of moral virtues of the students has not been effective.

    Sir, we do not profit in adapting education to meet social development and national needs. We should not do it at the expense of inculcating the ethical concept and character building in the students. If a person is brought up to be a specialist or a professor, but is lacking in morals, character or ethical concept, then of what use is he to our society? So we should not try to educate our students into becoming robots without a sense of morality and responsibility to society. Therefore, moral education is very important.

    Sir, I therefore hope that the Minister will pay attention to this very important matter and make adjustments, if necessary, to include ethics or civics as one of the examination subjects, so that we can bring up a generation of students with moral character and imbued with a sense of loyalty and patriotism. Only then can the future of our country be assured.

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, as expected the Ministry of Education has attracted a large number of speakers in this Budget debate. The reason is that in the last analysis education decides the performance of the nation. A creditable performance of the nation depends on the

Column: 976

collective courage, determination, ability and the social morality of the people. Thus if the education of the State ensures that every citizen develops with these potentials, then collectively the nation should perform successfully.

    Now that the education system has been restructured again, and this time we hope for some appreciable period, I wish to make some observations on the restructuring as announced and the implications arising from it.

    At the outset, Sir, the problem of sufficient classes and teachers comes to mind. Though the majority of primary school pupils will be completing the primary education in seven years (as that will be the normal course of primary education), the Minister has stated that about 40% of primary school pupils will be completing primary education in six years.

    Thus, as the Minister has announced, there will be in operation two sets of upper primary classes in the primary schools. Now, if you take the hypothetical case of a school having two Primary III classes at the outset, and if after assessment, eight pupils from the first class and 15 pupils from the second class, making 23 in all, are found suitable for six years' primary education and the remaining 27 pupils from the first class and 20 pupils from the second class, making 47 in all, are found suitable for seven years' primary education, then for Primary IV, you will, have one class of 23 pupils for six years' primary education and two classes for seven years' primary education comprising one class of 35 pupils and another of 12 pupils (that is, if you apply the ratio of 35 pupils to a class). If the position rests there, it means that after the assessment one additional class is created and one additional teacher is required. If adjustments are made, it must mean transfers of pupils and teachers for that year. How has the Ministry planned to resolve these problems? And incidentally, Sir, thinking aloud, what will be the stand of the Singapore Teachers' Union on these problems? But the important thing is

Column: 977

that parents must be satisfied that the results of the assessment must not be manipulated for the purpose of administrative expediency at the expense of the true academic ability of the pupils.

    It has been announced that the decision of whether a pupil should take six or seven years to complete his primary education will be based on a "continual assessment of his academic performance".

    I should think that the assessment itself should be based on certain standard forms and criteria of evaluating the academic performance of the pupil. If not, the disparities in the evaluations between different schools applying individualistic forms and criteria will not achieve a fair assessment of the pupils' performances. Have the forms and criteria of assessment been worked out? If not, I imagine they will be worked out soon. And when they are worked out, can they be applied fairly to assess the pupil's academic performance in Primary I in 1973 and Primary II in 1974 when this continual assessment was then not contemplated? How and to what extent will the pupil's performance in the second language in the first three years be decisive in determining whether the pupil does primary education in six years or seven years?

    It has been announced that normal primary education will be seven years and that the majority of primary pupils will complete their education in seven years. But it has also been announced, as I have pointed out earlier, that about 40% of primary pupils will complete the primary education in six years. This cannot be regarded as an exception. And although it has been announced that corrective reassessment will be made at the end of Primary IV, parents generally will regard the assessment at the end of Primary III as crucial since they still see promise of a better future for their children through the OCE, the HSC and beyond.

3.00 p.m.

    Parents will regard the assessment at the end of Primary III as a more or less

Column: 978

conclusive determination of their children's future, that is, whether they are blue collar or white collar workers. This being so, they expect the more able and experienced teachers to be assigned to teach in Primary Is, IIs and IIIs. Nor should these teachers be transferred before three years at least. I am sure that no relief teachers will be assigned to these classes in the future.

    As regards the PSLE and beyond, the Minister has stated that the PSLE will be a grading exercise to channel pupils into different forms of secondary education and training. Apart from the "0" and "A" levels in the academic, technical and commercial streams, there will be a variety of courses combining general education with technical training or apprenticeship scheme plan for a career in the industrial, commercial and service sectors.

    The Minister has announced that the restructured system at the secondary level will operate in 1979. He has also announced that the restructured process will begin with Primary III pupils this year and the 1975 batch of Primary IV pupils will continue but making only one other attempt for the PSLE. Thus in three years commencing in 1976 these primary pupils will be graded at the end of 1978 for the restructured system at the secondary level in 1979. So at the end of 1978 there will be grading of PSLE pupils to decide whether they should do courses leading to the GCE or HSC or any of the other courses for a career in the industrial, commercial and service sectors. Such grading must be based on revised upper primary curriculum to operate in 1976, that is, next year. Can the Minister at this stage give an outline description of the other courses? When will the curriculum for operation in 1976 be ready this year and be made public?

    I have raised these queries in order that the public can grasp the system fully, since the matter of children's education is always a matter of utmost concern to parents.

[Mr Deputy Speaker in the Chair]



    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Education Ministry is a very interesting Ministry as far as Singapore is concerned. It seems to be undergoing changes every so often that the result is chaos, confusion and puzzlement to everyone. Even those in the Ministry are confused as to what they are supposed to do. Worse, in schools the policy changes so often that principals and staff do not know exactly what is really required. What is the future of education in Singapore?

    May I ask whether these changes or restructuring are really necessary. Can we not implement them in stages and with great patience? The policy directives from the Education Ministry are issued so rapidly that before one directive can be carried out effectively a new one is issued. We seem to make use of the present generation of students and teachers as guinea pigs. I do not know whether this restructuring is a wise move because the changes have been so rapid that we will not be able to see the results until the students leave the secondary schools. And by that time probably they will not know what hell they have gone through. Let us be a bit more patient and give it a little more thought. I am not saying that the changes are bad. I am not saying that the policies are bad. The policy of bilingualism is extremely good. It is necessary for Singapore's survival.

Column: 980

Carry on by all means, but do so in stages. The Ministry should not just issue directives and instruct the principals to put them into practice overnight.

    Sir, I notice that there are 125 vacancies for English teachers in primary schools and 215 in the secondary schools in the English stream as at 1st March, 1975. This gives a figure of 340, which, I must say, is very high. To make matters worse, I notice there were 301 resignations within a period of 14 months. What is being done to fill these vacancies? 340 vacancies are being filled by relief teachers, some of whom come today and disappear tomorrow. They are not teachers in the real sense of the word. They are merely filling the gap. How can we have a good education system if 340 vacancies are filled by relief teachers? This is a very sad state of affairs.

    In the past the Institute of Education, formerly known as the Teachers' Training College, used to recruit teachers by the hundreds and produce teachers by the hundreds too. Unfortunately, after the TTC was renamed the Institute of Education, it has become another white elephant. Many accommodation units in the former College are as good as haunted. Many teachers have been transferred or opted out. There are a few of them left. To make matters worse, students who intend to take up teaching as a profession have to pay. Now, give us the answer in one breath who really wants to become a teacher today, with all the headaches and pressure of work? The stresses and strains are not really worth the money they get for their training. Even the courses organised by the Institute of Education have to be paid for by the teachers. No wonder we have 340 vacancies! 301 resignations had taken place in the last two years. What has been done to recruit more teachers to fill the vacancies? 340 vacancies means 340 teachers less.

    May I at this stage ask what is the purpose of the Education Fund? A lot of money is collected from the foreign students studying in schools or colleges in Singapore. If these funds are used

Column: 981

for the good of the Singapore citizens, then I say the fund has its purpose. Unfortunately I do not understand why a large sum of money is collected from students who study in private or commercial schools. These private schools are not in the least subsidised. Yet any student who wants to gain entry into these private schools has to pay to the Education Fund before he is allowed to continue his studies. I feel this is ethically wrong. We do not subsidise private schools. Why do we collect money from students who are studying in private schools? If it is the case with Government schools, it is understandable.

    Sir, I understand that some school children are given fund raising cards for donations to the school fund just before the school holidays. They are instructed to collect as much as possible. When the school reopens these cards are handed back to the teachers. Some children who have not collected the targeted amount are given back the cards and instructed to continue to collect up to the required amount. I wonder why these students are asked to collect up to a certain expected amount. This might induce the children to do something irregular for fear of being harassed by the teachers.

    At this point let me ask why GCE "A" level in Commerce course is not allowed to be conducted in private schools. This course is only done in a Government school. There are certain schools capable of conducting such a course, and I feel that some of them may produce better results than the Government schools.

    Furthermore, on the subject of courses, let me also ask why is a restriction imposed on teachers who wish to do a course on their own? To give an example, if a teacher in the academic stream wants to do a technical course, permission is refused. The result is that the teacher is frustrated. Why must we restrict teachers who are keen to improve themselves and who will be of benefit to our education system later on?

Column: 982



    Sir, how far has the posting of teachers and' students nearest their homes been carried out? I still notice that a great number of teachers and students are put in~ schools quite a distance away from their homes. Can the Minister look into the matter?

    Finally, I will I would like to know when results of the recent teachers exercise be known? I hope greater number of them will be, thus causing lesser dissatisfaction. Teachers are very important in education of children. Their importance is next to the parents. If the teachers not properly educated, they not produce good students. If the re well educated they will be of benefit to the students.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as the sixth under this subhead I am somewhat at a disadvantage for the simple reason that whatever I want to been very eloquently and put across by hon. Members spoken before me. But I feel nonetheless say something on this restructured education scheme because it has aroused considerable interest both from within and is House.

    I think that, of all the changes in the educational policy that have taken place past decade or so, the recent have been the most sensible they are oriented towards the well-being and interest; unlike previous changes which were tailored the political, social, economic manpower objectives. The recent are not geared to meet such objectives but more to cater to the well-the child in school.

    Two features of these changes demonstrate this. One is that schooling has been extended to 11 years in both primary and secondary levels instead of 10 years. In fact, all of us in this House were brought up under the 11-year education system. It was only a decade

Column: 983

or so ago that the 11-year education system was reduced to 10 years, and I suspect that at that time the reason for the reduction of one year's schooling was purely economic: the Government wanted to save money. I could see no other reason for the reduction of schooling from 11 to 10 years except this economic reason. And the price paid for that reduction was that children were put under heavier pressure to cope with a certain amount of knowledge to be acquired both in primary and secondary schools.

    As Members will know, in recent years because of economic and political developments, new requirements have come into the picture. More objectives are pumped into the education system, and more knowledge for the children to acquire. Even under the old system, where there had been many subjects for children to learn, 11 years were considered a desirable period for completion of the primary and secondary education; what more then if they have got more to learn now? It is only logical to conclude that a 10-year period would not be a desirable period. That is the reason why in the past few years there have been complaints from parents particularly about the pressure put on their children in the schools. So an extension of another year helps to relieve that pressure. This feature in itself demonstrates that this is for the good of the children.

    The second feature of the recent restructured education scheme is the removal of the Primary VI entrance examination (PSLE) as a means to determine whether a child could continue with secondary education. I think many of us have heard of complaints and are quite aware of this problem of examination phobia, where everything is geared towards examination. A child is measured by the examination results. The system is a very imperfect one. A child is condemned for life if he fails his Primary VI entrance examination. Any teacher

Column: 984

will know that passing or failing this entrance examination is no foolproof criterion in determining whether a child is capable of continuing his education or not. Not only was there anxiety on the part of parents and children over this entrance examination in the previous system which caused a lot of cramming of studies and private tuition but it also made schooling a very unpleasant experience for the children. By removing this requirement, education should become an interesting experience in school. Therefore, we have removed a feature which condemns a child, rightly or wrongly, by denying him an opportunity to continue with his education after primary school if he fails his primary six entrance examination. With this restructured education system an examination is no longer needed to determine whether a child should or should not proceed to secondary school. I think this is extremely desirable and in the interests of the children.

    There exists a prejudice against blue-collar work and a preference for white-collar work. The result is that certain prejudices are created against certain types of jobs.
